story: :root What are the Pandora Papers  Biggest leak of financial secrets in history explainedA vast coalition of journalists from around the world have uncovered millions of files pertaining to the offshore financial activity of a host world leaders and public figures. Here we explain what the Pandora Papers areTony Blair was among the highest profile names to appear in the Pandora Papers Image: GettyByHarry Thompson:,  Oct | comments The Pandora Papers are the latest and greatest in a series of major leaks relating to the shadowy underworld of offshore tax havens and people who use them.The leaks shed light on the activities of some of the worldaposs richest and most powerful people, after work by over  journalists from  media organisations in  countries sted through nearly  million documents from  dferent offshore service companies. The investigation, which has thrown up the names of dozens of world leaders and hundreds of public officials, was run by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalistsin Washington DC and was spearheaded in the UK by BBC Panorama and .The data, which amounted to . terabytes, does not necessarily imply that those discussed have done wrong, but rather lts the lid on the prolic use of offshore accounts. They raise a iety of questions about how the super-wealthy shield their assets, taxation, evasion, and money laundering and are potentially embarrassing for current and former leaders and public figures who may have in the past criticised similar practices. Who are some of the biggest names involved In the UK, perhaps the highest profile figure is Tony Blair and his we Cherie, who did not have to pay £, of stamp duty on a London property after acquiring the offshore firm that owned it.There is no suggestion the pair tried to avoid tax and the purchase was legal. In a statement, the couple said the transaction had been completed “in a normal way through reputable estate agents,” themselves having “nothing whatever to do with the original company nor those behind it”. They added they had “never used offshore schemes either to hide transactions or avoid tax”. The Queenaposs crown estate has also drawn attention during the findings, after it was revealed it had paid  million to the family of Azerbaijani president Ilham Aliyev, over the period of two decades infor part of their London property portfolio. The crown estate has since launched an inquiry.The files are also purported to include revelations regarding a number of Conservative party donors. According to , donor Viktor Fedotov co-owned a company once accused of playing a part in a major corruption scandal. Mr Fedotovaposs lawyers said there is no evidence whatsoever of any wrongdoing.Elsewhere, other high profile cases include the King or Jordan, Abdullah al-Hussein, whose  million property empire hidden through offshore accounts has been exposed. The revelation is likely to cause a stir in Jordan where protesters have faced prison time in the past for asking questions about the Kingaposs private property. His lawyers say he has done nothing wrong. It has also been alleged that the documents include information on Russian President Vladimir Putinaposs inner cirlce, Kenyaaposs President Uhuru Kenyatta, as well as Indian cricket legend Sachin Tendulkar, supermodel Claudia Schfer and singer Shakira among a host of others. Mr Kenyatta said said he would respond comprehensively upon hisfrom a state visit, adding the reports: Go a long way in enhancing the financial transparency and openness that we require in Kenya and around the globe. Ms Schfer has reportedly told the ICIJ that she correctly pays taxes in the UK, while Shakira has released a statement her accounts referenced in the Pandora papers were correctly registered with Spanish authorities. The close-knit family will often go out together and Tracy says they have more energy to play with the little ones. It’s strange because we’ve got such a great family dynamic, she says. We’re all very close - I donapost knowthat’s the age factor. If we go on a night out, we go out with our boys and their partners and their friends. It’s very social. We’ve got goals in the garden and lots of toys for the grandchildren, she adds. You’ve got that energy to spend with them because you are younger. aposLe is what you make of itapos Tracy says that despite having a successful career and raised a loving family, the couple have been frowned upon for many years. People will say, aposOh we’re having our first grandchildapos and they’re in their fties. I say, aposThat’s lovely, Iaposve got seven, it’s great being a grandmaapos, she says They look at me and go, aposYou’re not old enough to be a grandma, let alone sevenapos. You almost feel like you’re being taken back to that stage [of being a young mum] again. It’s about thinking it’s not the end of the world. Le is what you make of it, she says. Keep going at what you want in le. Everything is still achievable. The logic behind opening up the country despite the near certainty that cases would rise was that the roll-out of the coronavirus vaccine - which has now seen about % of the population jabbed twice - would mostly break the link between infections and deaths. For the most part it has. Yesterday  people lost their lives to Covid- in the UK and , new cases were reported. On January , when things were at their most bleak, , died and , positive tests were ed. The data show that as phenomenally effective as the vaccines have been at protecting people from the virus, the shield it offers is not total. More than  million adults in the UK have not been jabbed, meaning they are at much higher risk of catching, getting ill with and dying from Covid-. Department of Health data shows that unvaccinated people aged  and over are almost four times as likely to die after contracting the bug.  With such a large chunk of the population not opting to get vaccinated, the potential for cases and deaths to rise signicantly higher is great, particularly as the cold winter months draw in. Already the NHS is struggling to keep up with demand heightened by the virus.On Wednesday evening at least  ambulances were seen queuing up outside the Royal Stoke University Hospital in Hartshill, Staffordshire.Health bosses admitted that emergency departments across the area were under aposvery signicant pressureapos. Thankfully protection against severe disease, hospitalisation and death still remains strong at that point. In a bid to protect the more vulnerable, the government has said all over-s, younger adults with health conditions and frontline health and care workers can get a third booster jab. Winter cold and flu is making a comeback Another serious issue that may aggravate the pandemic over the coming months is the flu. Today the government announced the biggest flu jab programme in the NHS’s history, with more than  million people in England eligible for a free vaccine.  Now that mask and social distancing mandates have been dropped, transmissions of the flu is likely to shoot up. Last year cases of the virus remained incredibly low, meaning natural immunity to the potentially deadly disease is likely rock-bottom at the moment. As well as piling more pressure on the NHS, catching flu and Covid at the same time is not only very possible, but signicantly increases the chance of death.By the worst estimates, , people could die from flu alone this year - compared to an average toll of ,.New strains may emerge A continuing point of concern are coronavirus strains, and the potential for another mutation. If the flu, increasing deaths among the unvaccinated and a new strain were to all hit at the same time, the government may have some dficult decisions to make. title: couple turned away easyjet flight
story: :root Couple turned away from EasyJet flight over illogical Covid-testing policyJayne Nicholls and Alexander Doory were turned away at the gate of their Naples flight at Luton Airport after finding out their fit-to-fly test had to be valid within  hours of arriving in Italy not departing from the UKJayne Nicholls and Alexander Doory were refused at the gate of their EasyJet flight to Naples, Italy at Luton Airport Image: Jayne NichollsByShannen HeadleyAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct | commentsA couple who were turned away from their EasyJet flight by staff over a Covid-testing policy has branded the decision unfair and illogical. Jayne Nicholls and Alexander Doory were refused at the gate of their Naples flight at Luton Airport over an unclear ruling by the airline.They were told on October  that their fit-to-fly Covid results would not be accepted because they were outside the set time limitations, LeicestershireLive reports. Jayne said: We had our fit to fly test at .am at Colingtonaposs at East Midlands. They asked us where we were going and where we were flying so we thought we were sorted.  But when we got to the gate, we saw a young lad before us getting turned away. He looked really panicky, but he could only speak Italian so we couldnapost find out what was wrong. The -year old and her partner were told that their test result had to be valid  hours to when they landed in Italy - not  hours ahead of their departure time. The flight was scheduled for .am and was due to land .am UK time. The couple were  minutes shy of meeting the policy requirements.  She said: The whole thing was really confusing. It should be called fit-to-land. It wasnapost logical or fair and thataposs the worst thing. Some passengers were given a -minute leeway, but we were still out by  minutes so we were turned away. To me, itaposs just not clear. We lost money for airport car parking, flights plus we had to purchase new flights, new covid tests and new airport parking. Iaposm strong, Iaposm not a stressed-out person - but the situation actually pushed me over the edge. There wasnapost any apologies - we werenapost allowed to ask questions, and there wasnapost anyone that would help us or answer a question. EasyJet says the requirement was put in place by the Italian government. They urge customers to research Covid-related restrictions of their destinations.for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email. A spokesman for EasyJet said: Passengers travelling from the UK the Italian authorities require a negative Covid test result to have been taken within  hours of arrival which unfortunately the passengers didn’t have. Like all airlines, easyJet is required to comply with the requirements of the local authorities in all destinations where we operate. Unfortunately, as the passengers were unable to provide negative test results inside the timeframe required by the Italian authorities, they were unable to travel. “Due to the fast changing, complex and widely ranging Government policies around restrictions in place across Europe, we are alerting customers to the importance of checking current local travel requirements ahead of their flight via email and on easyJet via our Covid- Help Hub, where they can also find access to government website links and the most up to date travel information. We always remind customers that it is their responsibility to ensure they meet entry requirements and will continue to advise them to check the local Government requirements prior to departure. “The safety and wellbeing of our customers and crew is our highest priority.” Comment MORE ON EasyJet" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. In that category, .% of children tested positive for Covid-, more than  in , compared to .% in the previous week. Schools in England have been open for around a month since the summer break and some epidemiologists have voiced concerns about rising cases among pupils. The East of England is the only area that has not seen an increase in infections, as the ONS said the trend in the region is uncertain.  The average prevalence of Covid- in England is estimated to be around one in  people - the highest level since the end of August. Infections have been rising for a second week, having been at one in  people in the previous week. The ONS last reported one in  people infected with Covid- in the week ending August , before children in England ed to school. story: :root DIY-savvy mum-of-three transforms her very plain dining room for just £Mum-of-three Maria Thomas, , from Kidderminster, Worcestershire, took inspiration from expensive ling posts on Pinterest and Facebook - but decided to make her own unique installation with just £Mum-of-three Maria Thomas, pictured with fiance George, used stick on LED lights and planks of wood to make the unique installation Image: Jam Press Maria ThomasByAmy WaltersRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA DIY-savvy mum-of-three has transformed her dining room for £ with stick-on LED lights and planks of wood. Maria Thomas, , an administrator from Kidderminster, Worcestershire, felt the wall by her familyaposs dining table was very plain. She wanted to put her own twist on the room, and created an iconic installation on the cheap.Maria developed the concept from ling posts on Pinterest and Facebook - most of which used expensive components.So the mum-of-three decided to create a budget DIY version of the popular look. And social media users have been blown away by the £ hack – that just requires some wood batons, LED lights, paint, glue and nails.  Maria, who is mum to Spencer, , George,  and Ollie, four, also roped in her fiancé, George, , who she says did majority of the hard labour, while she was in control of making the project pretty. “George bought the wood batons and then drew the outline on the wall where we wanted them,” Maria said. “Once he attached the batons with wood glue and a couple of nails from BQ, which cost £, we then had to decide where to place the lights. “We bought some stick-on LED lights from Amazon for £, which are in a smart plug so Alexa can then turn off and on.  He doubled the batons so you wouldn’t be able to see them and then sanded the wood down until smooth. Iaposm thrilled with the finished result and super proud of George. The couple finished off their new ling by adding two coats of aposAlfresco Dusky Blushapos paint from Frenchic at £. This isnapost the first DIY project the pair have sunk their teeth into – in fact, they have spent the last two years sprucing up their home. Maria said: “We have always done dferent bits around the house but I’ve only recently been doing furniture.  “I love making things look pretty – not just my house, but I upcycle furniture and give them a whole new lease of le. “I recently painted all my kitchen cupboards and changed the handles and it’s made such a dference on a really cheap budget. “We have redecorated everywhere in our home and have nearly finished the kitchen.” Maria decided to share her latest project on Facebook, where the post has since racked up , likes so far.  One person called it a “game changer, while someone  added “How nice does this look.” “Wow! So luxurious looking! wrote a third person, adding a clapping emoji. “I generally hate wall ing, I know it’s the trend now but this is something ...luv it!” another user wrote. [sic] A fth user added: “Absolutely beautul!!” “Oh my, we need this!” wrote someone .  Maria has more DIY plans for coming months, including building a media wall with a fire after Christmas. She urges anyone who wants to do DIY for less to take their time and compare prices to get the best deals. The mum added: “It’s scary at first as everything looks awful to start with. “Whilst doing one room, the rest of the house suffers with mess which is the worst bit. “Just take your time to get it right, research ideas and compare prices for items.” Comment MORE ON AmazonBQ PLCproperty newsProperty CareDiyersDIY SOS" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts from our Property Market newsletterSubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news former-pride-britain-winner-who-"Pictures of legendary Bee lady Jean BishopByStephen WhiteAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct | commentsA former Pride of Britain winner who raised more than £, for charity has died aged . Jean Bishop, who was known as Hullaposs Bee Lady because she dressed up as the insect to collect money for Age UK, died peacefully on October . In , she received the freedom of the city and was awarded a British Empire Medal in the New Year Honours. At the time she was askedshe would retire and said: There isn’t such a word.” Jean, who was born in Lincs. before moving to East Yorks. when she was young, was just a few months shy of her centenary.  She was known for dressing up in her bee costume and rattling her charity box throughout Hull to raise money for Age UK. The bee costume came about when borrowed it from Age UK and realised her distinctive outfit helped raise a lot of money. Jean later had her daughter make her bee costume with hula hoops and charity shop fabric.  Speaking in  about her work, she said: “I didn’t want to put the costume on at first, but when I did it went down like a bomb.” In the same year, she was recognised by the Queen for her dedication to helping others less fortunate than herself. As she received her medal, the monarch asked Jean why she wasn’t wearing her trademark outfit.  She replied she would, but it would have meant she “would have had to have paid for two seats on the train”.In , Jean was recognised as Fundraiser of the Year at the Pride of Britain Awards, with a bee suit-clad David Walliams presenting her with the award.In , she opened the Jean Bishop Integrated Care Centre, which provides out-of-hospital care for older people in Hull.  The centre, which opened during the week the NHS celebrated its th birthday, was named after her to recognise the impact she had made in her home city. She was only the second woman to be granted the freedom of Hull, following anti-apartheid campaigner Helen Suzman in , and was also celebrated in board game form. Pam Morgan-Davies, CEO of Age UK Hull, said Mrs Bishop was a “complete one-off”. She said: She was groundbreaking, both in the way that she fundraised and how she made people of all ages feel comfortable. “The number of people who remember putting money in her tin when they were little, then they would come up with their kids or their grandkids and say, ‘I used to give you money when I was little’ - she loved that.”  Karl Turner, Labour MP for East Hull, paid tribute to the bright and bubbly woman. He wrote: I am deeply saddened to hear of the passing of Jean Bishop at the age of  this morning. I had the honour of opening the Jean Bishop Centre with her a few years ago. She was a bright and bubbly woman and leaves behind an incredible legacy in our city. Rest in peace Jean.You can make a donation to Jeanaposs chosen charities and share your own memories and tributes to Hullaposs very own Bee Lady and view her funeral notice here. story: :root It doesn’t feel like work! - mum spices things up with surprising new careerAs KFC launches its limited edition Zinger Popcorn Bucket, we celebrate the thrill of trying something newAdvertorialByLaura Tait:,  Oct When it comes to decision making do you play it safe, or seek out fun and adventure  If you fancy yourself as a thrill seeker, then Zinger Popcorn is for you. To celebrate the launch of Zinger Popcorn Bucket - available for a limited time only - we decided to champion people who like to spice things up, including Hannah Murphy, . When she reached a career crossroads in , Hannah struck out on a new adventurous course, and almost a decade on has no regrets about her bold decision. When I was made redundant from my eight-year career as a flight attendant, flying both domestically and between the UK and Japan, I saw it as an opportunity set myself a new challenge, and have new adventures, says Hannah who lives in Southampton with her husband and three children, Angelina, , Archie,  and Adriana, five. At the time I was a single mum of one after my previous relationship ended, and the ‘sensible’ decision would have been to take a - desk job, something stable but didnapost challenge me. That’s just not me though, I have to love what I do and find joy in it every day. Instead, Hannah trained as a fitness instructor and began to incorporate a hula hoop into her training. It wasn’t just a useful exercise tool, great for toning and core strength, it was so much fun. The moment I started hula hooping, I was transported back to my childhood, it was really liberating. As word got out about Hannah’s hula hooping prowess, friends and family began to ask for lessons, followed by requests from local schools for Hannah to come in and teach children how to hula hoop.  It snowballed and before I knew it, I had so much interest in hula hooping fitness classes, I had to train other instructors to help me. I went on to create a training programme called Globe Fit and today I have teachers all around the world, from Australia to America, all teaching my programme. I love teaching hula hooping, particularly adults, because they might start off a bit self-conscious and inhibited but soon their inner child is released and they just go for it! I’ve taught people aged from teenagers to eighty-year-olds. Last year, I hosted the first ever world hula hooping championship, which will be taking place again later this year. After launching the UKaposs first hula hooping championship in , which took place in Fareham, Hampshire, Hannah decided to go global in . Not even a pandemic could stop her with the event going virtual and around twenty-five competitors, women and men of all ages and abilities, taking part from as far afield as India, America and Australia. I had a  of four judges, including John Parnell aka Hoop Guy who appeared on Britainaposs Got Talent in . Competitors submitted videos of themselves performing with their hoop, and were marked on everything from skill to tricks they could do, with the  judging the videos.  The second world championship will take place in December this year, again virtually, and I hope to have even more people taking part. It’s amazing to be a part of people experiencing something new and fun, it doesn’t feel like work! Hannah’s story is a great example of how le can get better when you try something new, soyou already love Popcorn chicken - tasty pops of  per cent chicken breast, perfect to nibble on by themselves or as a side - then itaposs time to turn up the heat. Popcorn Chicken Zinger is the same delicious chicken and moreish crunch, but KFC have pumped up the spice for those who can handle a kick. driver smashed through barriers at a level crossing after they reversed over the railway line. The trucker was captured on camera slowly driving backwards over the track as a train approached at Wedgwood Station, in Stoke-on-Trent, Staffordshire, on Thursday. The HGV can be seen making it most of the way across the crossing before the gate came down on top of the truck - ripping the barrier clean off. It caused major disruption to passengers travelling on the West Coast main line between Crewe and Stoke as the route had to be closed.  Engineers worked for one-and-half hours to fix the barrier by pm following the incident, which happened at .pm. Network Rail today released the heart-stopping footage and warned motorists never to reverse over level crossings. James Dean, Network Rail’s West Coast South route director, said: “It’s almost unbelievable that this lorry driver decided to reverse over this level crossing, putting not only them but also the oncoming train and its passengers in danger.  “It’s not advice we usually need to give but now we must also stress to motorists to never reverse over a level crossing as you won’t see the warning lights. He was embroiled in a long-running legal battle with Madeleine’s parents after writing a book accusing them of covering up her death, something they have always strenuously denied.Now Amaral has written a second book - Maddie: Enough Lies - in which he says prime suspect Christian Brueckner is innocent.He claims German prosecutors have turned the convicted paedophile into a “man-made Frankenstein”. Amaral, , accuses them of doing a botch job as part of a “discredited desire” to link Brueckner the crime. And he says Brueckner has been made the prime suspect because of a “biased” German investigation. In his -page book, which is set to be published next week, he also makes fresh slurs against Kate and Gerry McCann. Last month he repeated  allegations accusing the couple of being the “main culprits” for their daughter’s disappearance. The McCannaposs have always vigorously denied any involvement in Madeleineaposs disappearance.  Amaral cruelly told German newspaper Bild he has “no doubt” Madeleine’s kidnapping was staged as part of a cover-up. Kate and Gerry, from Rothley, Leics, were left heartbroken at their daughter’s disappearance. The couple have spent over  years trying to find her and still believe she is alive somewhere. They have also campaigned for missing children charities across the globe and highlighted other tragic cases.  Amaral previously claimed in a controversial book that Kate and Gerry covered up their daughter’s accidental death. The couple sued in the Portuguese courts, sparking a bitter ten-year legal battle that still rumbles on. news uk-news meet-princess-dianas-spencer-family-"Spencer: Official teaser trailer from STX FilmsByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Oct | commentsIt is one of the most eagerly-anticipated movies of the year and delves into Princess Dianaaposs decision to end her marriage to Prince Charles. And last night the film, called Spencer, got its UK premiere with Twilight actress Kristin Stewart taking on the coveted role of Diana. Set in , the film documents the late princess spending three days with the royal family at Sandringham, where she decides to finally end her turbulent marriage to the future King. The filmaposs title takes its name from Dianaaposs family name of Spencer. Before she was married, she was known as Lady Diana Spencer. But who is part of the Spencer family now, and what do they do  Here we reveal all... The model newlywed  Among the most well-known of the current crop of Spencers is Dianaaposs niece and Princes William and Harryaposs younger cousin, Lady Kitty Spencer.The -year-old hit the headlines in July when she married wealthy businessman Michael Lewis, , in a stunning three-day wedding in Italy.She wore a series of gowns by Dolce  Gabbana with her main dress, which had an intricate floral lace design, a high neck, long sleeves and puffed shoulders, reportedly taking six months to create. The couple exchanged their vows in front of celebrity guests that included singer Pixie Lott, and Idris Elbaaposs we Sabrina at the Villa Aldobrandini in Rome.Kitty is Earl Spenceraposs oldest child and grew up in South Africa with her mother Victoria. She read psychology at the University of Cape Town and has modelled for brands including Dolce  Gabbana and Bvlgari.  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. She also scored invites to the wedding of her cousins William and Harry and her Instagram account shows her at fashion shows in cities such as London and Milan.Although the monarchy has now changed to put sons and daughters on an equal footing in terms of ascending to the throne, British primogeniture law has not been changed to peers such as dukes and earls. So her father Earl Spenceraposs title will go to his eldest son Louis rather than Lady Kitty. Glamorous twins  Sometimes joining their sister Kitty at events and parties are twins Lady Eliza and Lady Amelia Spencer.They were born in  and grew up in South Africa and were just five when their late aunt Diana died.Earlier this year, they gave a rare joint interview in Tatler where they shared fond memories of their incredibly warm, maternal and loving aunt. Speaking about Dianaaposs death in , Eliza said: As a child, I realised the enormity of the loss for my father and family. It was only later that I came to understand the signicance of the loss of her as a figure in the world. We always just knew her as our aunt. Growing up in South Africa, I really had very little idea of how signicant she was in the world until I was much older. Curiously, Amelia didnapost attend cousin Harry wedding to Meghan in , but Eliza was there. Both twins are models and are represented by Storm Management.Prince Harry-lite Another member of the Spencer family is Kitty, Amelia and Elizaaposs younger brother Louis, who has been dubbed aposthe worldaposs most eligible bachelorapos as well as aposPrince Harry liteapos. He is a fair few years younger than his royal cousins William and Harry but in the past, it has been reported that he is close to them.Louis, , is said to be apossuper privateapos but earlier this year, he played a starring role in sister Kittyaposs wedding, as he walked her down the aisle.One day he will inherit the familyaposs ,-acre Althorp estate in Northamptonshire as his father, Earl Spenceraposs heir apparent - despite having three older sisters. Kitty previously said: Weaposve grown up understanding that itaposs Louis to inherit, and Louis will do an incredible job. Head of the family  The current head of the Spencer family and holding the title of Earl Spencer is Dianaaposs younger brother Charles.He is the custodian of the familyaposs Althorp estate in Northamptonshire and has been married three times. As well as having children Kitty, Eliza, Amelia and Louis, he also has younger children Edmund, Lara and Charlotte.Charles counts the Queen as one of his godparents and was extremely close to Diana - delivering a moving eulogy at her funeral in Westminster Abbey in . However, when his eldest daughter Kitty wed this summer, there was reportedly no sign of her father at the nuptials.An insider claimed the Earl may have skipped his daughteraposs big day due to a shoulder-related injury. A source told MailOnline at the time: Charles recently suffered an injury and perhaps that will be the reason for him not travelling, but it is just easier for everyone that he is not there. Prince Charlesaposs ex  Lady Sarah McCorquodale is Dianaaposs eldest sister and even briefly dated Prince Charles as a teenager. She married Neil McCorquodale in  and they have three children - Emily, George and Celia. Diana was said to be close to Sarah and she sometimes accompanied her on engagements as a lady-in-waiting. After Dianaaposs death, she accompanied Prince Charles alongside her other sister Jane to bring the princess back to the UK.In , she attended the christening of Harryaposs son Archieaposs christening and was at the unveiling of a statue of Diana in July.Royal wedding star Lady Jane Fellowes is another of Dianaaposs older sisters and is married to Robert Fellowes - a former private secretary to the Queen. She has three children - Laura, Alexander and Eleanor - and gave readings at the funeral of her sister as well as at nephew Prince Harryaposs wedding in . news uk-news met-office-confirms-exact-date-"UK weather: Changeable weather predicted in later half of the weekByChantelle HeedsTim Hanlon:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsBrits have been enjoying tropical conditions at the start of October with an Indian summer bringing temperatures over C but a cold blast is on the way and snow is predicted by the end of the month.After rain and floods, this week has brought warm weather giving the chance for people to sit out in the sun but snow clouds are not too far away.Met Office senior meteorologist Greg Dewhurst says higher ground in northern England and northern Wales could see snowfall as well as mountains in Scotland, reported LancsLive.Greg said there is likely to be some snowy weather in higher parts as October moves into November. However, it is unlikely that low areas will experience snowfall.  He said: Likely areas to be affected are the Scottish mountains as well as higher ground in northern England and northern Wales. Low areas are unlikely to see any. It’s quite normal for this time of year. It comes as publications say a White Halloween is now feared, with odds slashed by bookies.  We better make the most of any balmy temperatures because the end of October looks set to be a big freeze, so much so that we make it odds on for snow to fall this month in the UK, said Coralaposs Harry Aitkenhead. We make it a - chance that this winter goes into the record books as the coldest the UK has ever had. Last week a blanket of snow hit Scotlandaposs highest peak with around cm falling on Ben Nevis.  Before the cold snap arrives on lower ground, Met forecaster Clare Nasir said that the country is having exceptionally mild weather this week. The air across the UK has been emersed by tropical conditions and what that means is that it is exceptionally mild as we head into Friday andyou catch some sunshine, feeling very warm throughout Friday afternoon, she said. Through the day we will see some sunshine for Wales, the Midlands, eventually northern parts of England and the West Country, always more rain towards the South East. Then this area of rain continues but it is mainly light rain, drizzle for the southern parts of the Highlands. To the north we see some brighter skies but the reason why we continue to see that rain warning for western Highlands and Argyle is because another pulse of rain will push up later on from the South West. Always a breeze in the north but the key thing about the weather like I said are the temperatures of C to C throughout the afternoon even where you see that cloud. Elsewhere, fog and low cloud slowly clearing to allow some warm sunshine for many, though staying cloudier in the far southeast. Tonight: Rain moving across parts of Northern Ireland and northwest Scotland, heavy at times. South and southeast England turning cooler with fog patches. Otherwise mostly cloudy with spots of light rain. Saturday: Fog lting over south and central England to leave warm sunshine. Cloudier where with rain in far northwest moving across Scotland and into north England whilst easing. Outlook for Sunday to Tuesday: Mainly dry Sunday after patchy drizzle clears the south, some blustery showers across the north. Rain for the northwest Monday but dry for most into the start of next week. story: :root Money-savvy bride spends just £ on wedding and ends up making a profit from gtsThe money savvy bride was able to cut costs by calling in the help of her friends, using second hand decorations and buying her dress onlineStaci, , and Grant, , tied the knot in a budget wedding that cost them just £ Image: @matjamesphotography Caters News AgencyByKaty-Rose MeaneyShiler Mahmoudi:,  Oct | commentsA money saving bride spent just £ on her big day, and even made a profit after receiving cash in gts on the big day. Bride Staci Gibson, , celebrated her marriage to Grant, , on a small budget complete with a registry office ceremony, a white dress and buffet reception.The happy couple from the West Midlands had a Covid wedding which meant that only  people could attend, but this meant that the cost was dramatically reduced.The newlyweds were able to pull off the wedding by using some savvy ideas to cut the cost. For her wedding look, Staci bought her wedding dress from ASOS which, thanks to a promo code, was a bargain at just £. What do you think of this story  Have your say in the comments  She paired the dress with a homemade bouquet, £ Primark heels and accessories from Claireaposs. A friend was able to do her bridal hair and makeup, and another friend who is a baker gted them with a cake. She said: We saved money on the things we thought were unnecessary like favours and gts for the bridal party. Focus on why youaposre getting married and who you want there not the bits no one remembers anyway. Staci added: My friend is a seamstress and she altered my dress for free and she made the girls their bridesmaid dresses. I paid just £ for the material.Even Grant had a discount on his suit, which we bought from Next and used a family discount rather than hire from a wedding shop.The couple even saved money on their wedding rings, as Grant decided to use his dadaposs wedding ring and Staci exchanged her engagement ring that had broken for a new set including an engagement ring and wedding band. news uk-news mum-blasts-selfish-eco-activists-"Furious motorist brands Insulate Britain protesters selfishByKelly-Ann MillsReporterRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct A mum on the school run slammed selfish eco activists after their M protest stopped her daughter getting to class on time. The womanaposs furious outburst came as Insulate Britain protesters flocked to dferent roads across the capital to cause traffic disruption today. Several dozen demonstrators spread themselves between Junction  of the M at Waltham Cross, Hertfordshire, and busy Old Street in east London. The enraged parent was driving her daughter to class along the M when protesters gathered close to the Enfield junction delayed her school run. As she passed the campaigners - who were sat in a row behind a barrier - the mum wound down her window.  She then called the activists selfish and a disgrace and slammed them for putting their cause above education. She said: Itaposs backing up, all because all you care about is insulating houses. My daughter is late to school, you are messing with childrenaposs education because you are selfish. The mum then starts to drive away when she spots the woman filming the altercation. I hope you got that on camera, she says. The camerawoman then asks the angry mum what she thinks about the demonstrators. I think itaposs a disgrace. An absolute disgrace, she said. Meanwhile, on Old Street protesters were accompanied by aposofficial observersapos following several violent clashes with motorists since starting their nationwide demonstration in September. Met Police are at the scene and said in a statement: We are responding to two protests this morning which are blocking roads.  Activists are disrupting traffic around Old Street roundabout, #Islington. Theyaposre also disrupting motorists at Junction  of the #M. Weaposre on scene and working quickly to get traffic moving. The force added: We know that some activists have used super glue to frustrate our efforts and to delay Londoneraposs even further. We train for these scenarios and have specialist teams on hand to help remove people and make arrests. We will share more information shortly. The activists ignored an injunction put in place to stop them blocking traffic. Just before am this morning an ambulance was photographed as it tried to get past the protestors in Islington. Insulate Britain wants the government to insulate and retrofit homes across the UK to cut climate emissions.  Its members have caused chaos on the M five times in the past fortnight and were threatened with imprisonmentthey ed to the motorway.More than  Insulate Britain campaigners have been arrested at the protests, the Department for Transport said.The blockades have affected Essex, Hertfordshire and Kent since starting on September .Speaking last week to LBC Tracey Mulligan for Insulate Britain said: We have certainly got everybody talking about insulation or avoiding the question of insulation. We have got people considering that our government is legally failing in their duty to protect us and I think weaposre showing that Priti Patel, unfortunately, is trying to scare us with an injunction and that shows her lack of character, not ours. You canapost put an injunction on hunger, you canapost put and injunction on physics, and we are terried for our childrenaposs future and sick of over , people dying each year from the choice of heating or eating. When asked about breaking the injunction, she said: I wouldnapost say we are happy, we are just putting things into the bigger context. We are tired of over seven million people having to choose between heating or eating and we know thataposs going to get worse with the energy crisis that weaposre facing now. story: :root Mum on Universal Credit cant afford kids bus fare after £ a week cutMum-of-two Cayleigh Davies and Tom Trigger are two of the people from the Woodrow area of Redditch who are struggling to make ends meet under the new Universal Credit regimeCayleigh Davies is having to find ways to make ends meet Image: BPM MediaByJane Tyler:,  Oct | commentsA mum faced with a Universal Credit cut has decided sheaposll have to stop giving her children bus fares to make ends meet. Mum-of-two Cayleigh Davies is one of millions of people who is now £ a week worse off thanks to the Conservative governmentaposs decision to cut the welfare payment.The cut came into force on Wednesday, Birmingham Mail reported. Cayleigh, , said the extra £ a week was hugely important to her and her two kids, aged  and . Things are already hard and we just about get by and that £ extra we got made such a dference, she said. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter I honestly donapost know what Iaposm going to cut back on - probably the childrenaposs bus fares as it isnapost too far for them to walk to school.As well as the income reduction, the prospect of spiralling utility prices is causing big headaches for some people.Tom Trigger, aged , now has his first home after a letime of living with his parents. Iaposve only been in my own place for three weeks so am dreading my first gas and electricity bill as Iaposve been reading about how much theyaposve shot up, he said.Luckily I work as a welder, but my girlfriend is a teacher whoaposs on Universal Credit and thataposs just been reduced by £ a week.But Iaposm not that worried about rising bills yet because I donapost know any dferent. Ask me in a month though and I may tell you something dferent. A -year-old mum of four, who didnapost want to be named, said the rising cost of living had forced her onto anti-depressants.  The woman, who was the victim of domestic violence, said despite working part-time at a major retailer and claiming Universal Credit, she was still close to poverty. I live like a pauper, she said. After Iaposve paid all my bills I have just £ - £ a week to buy food. I only put the heating on when itaposs really cold, otherwise I just put a jumper on Iaposve gone through all my bills and cancelled everything I donapost need and Iaposm very thrty. I got so worried about money, Universal Credit being reduced and all my bills going up that my doctor put me on anti depressants. All of these Universal Credit claimants live in the Woodrow area of Redditch, which has been named as one of Worcestershireaposs poorest areas. In the Woodrow Centre the Community Social Hub has just opened, providing cheap food for struggling families. It is run by mum-of-four Michelle Bridge, aged , who set up one in the Wirrall, Merseyside, which has proved very successful.  Since opening on September , it has seen  households use it - thataposs , people. Michelle fully expects that number to shoot up over the winter. Lots of people were just about managing before the pandemic, and then that happened and their lives fell apart, she said. People lost their jobs, relationships broke down because of lockdown, people had more babies and money got tight. The club is in a shop unit in Woodrow Centre and operates by people paying £ a year membership fees. For that, they get a £ food parcel, comprising food essentials, or they can buy food like bread for p, a big packet of porridge oats for p, as well as other food and toiletries for a fraction of the price theyaposd normally pay in a supermarket. It will get worse over winter as energy bills go up and people realise they havenapost got enough money to buy food, Michelle said. Then thereaposs the ending of that extra £ a week they got on Universal Credit - that will hit people really hard as theyaposve become reliant on over the last  months.  But we are here and will remain here for those who really need us. Kelly Messenger is  and has six children and has started volunteering at the club. Iaposm already struggling to make ends meet, so am dreading winter with everything going up, she said. Because Kellyaposs children are aged three, five-year-old twins, six, seven and eight she is unable to work and is reliant on benefits. She shares custody of them with her partner, but that means she only gets Child Benefit for two of the children as he has it for the others. I used to work in a shop but had to give that up when my youngest children came along, plus I had mental health issues too, she said. Itaposs going to be a tough winter money-wise, but Iaposd never cut things for the kids - all the savings I make will be for myself. The Community Social Hub has been my leline - I love volunteering here and means we can eat healthy meals. Kerry Snow is  and lives in a three bedroom house in Woodrow with her eight-year-old daughter, her grown-up son and his girlfriend and their baby, as well as her -year-old disabled mother.Losing that £ a week Universal Credit is something Iaposve been dreading ever since it was announced it was ending, she said.Thataposs a lot of money to me and my family and will mean making cutbacks - and then all my other bills will go up too. Janet and Phil Williams, both , who were shopping with their grandson, said they were lucky because they were pensioners.Phil, who used to work at Cadburyaposs and gets a private pension on top of his state pension, said: Weaposre lucky, but our daughter and everyone  with children is really going to struggle, especiallytheyaposre on Universal Credit.I feel really sorry for young families now because, eventhey work, they will still see all their bills rise. Local resident June Mitchell, aged , was also thankful that sheaposs a pensioner. I get state pension and also a bit of my ex-husbandaposs pension too, and I live on my own, so Iaposll just about get by, she said. But we should never have voted the Conservatives into power and as soon as thereaposs an election Iaposm voting them out. story: :root No wonder women no longer know who to trust after the death of Sarah EverardFor Fiona Phillips, the sight of a policeman is no longer reassuring or a sign that you’re in safe hands - now being able to trust in our public protectors is no longer a given, just who are women to look to and trust Patsy Stevenson, the -year-old flame-haired student who was filmed being roughly held down by police at the vigil following the murder of Sarah Everard Image: REUTERSopinionByFiona Phillips:,  Oct There are some stories I find very hard to believe and the following is a prime example:  police and security guards have intimidated Patsy Stevenson on a dating app. Patsy, the -year-old flame-haired student who was filmed being roughly held down by police at the vigil following the murder of Sarah Everard, says other police and security guards subsequently intimidated her on a dating app. Oh what larks! NOT.Since Sarah’s vigil, she claims around  police officers and security guards have deliberately “liked” her profile on the Tinder dating app. !What is WRONG with these neanderthals  Are they married  Have they got daughters, God forbid  What’s obvious is that they clearly seem to think that being in a unorm grants them a special privilege that prevents them from being pulled up for their filthy, threatening behaviour. Some of them will have sons who might well follow their dads’ macho examples.  Get all the latest news straight to your inbox.to one of the Mirroraposs newslettersSo can women trust police officers now  Have to say I’d feel a lot less safe in their companyI was approached by an officer on a dark night. Would he be friend or fatal foe Does knowing that a depraved officer killed a beautul young woman in the prime of her le, before burning her body and adding unspeakable insult to injury for her family, mean that we, as women, simply cannot trust the police  I’m not quite sure what we’re supposed to think now. For me and I suspect thousands of other women, the sight of a policeman is no longer a reassuring safety net nor a sign that you’re in safe hands so women are basically on their own now, on a dark night.  There are far too many unanswered questions. With a large proportion, it seems, of the public servants women are supposed to be able to trust now rendered potential offenders, just who are women to look to and trust  Now that we can’t automatically assume that a police officer is our best bet in a threatening situation, what are we supposed to do  Stay in and channel Miss Havisham  Hire a bodyguard each time we dare to venture out to make sure we come to no harm  For women, being able to trust in our public protectors is no longer a given. How can it be when a beautul, innocent soul was murdered, just for being a woman who had the misfortune to encounter a depraved man, a father, a husband, a police officer FGS, and now, thank the Lord, a ler. For women who live in my neighbourhood – not far from Sarah’s former neighbourhood – le hasn’t been the same since that dark night. He might be locked up but Wayne Couzens has affected OUR freedom too. title: raging dad rounded up vigilantes
story: :root Raging dad rounded up vigilantes to mow down men he believed sold drugs to his sonCraig Topen, from Dundee, used his Land Rover Freelander to hit two men before getting out of the vehicle and whacking another man with a golf club, Dundee Sherf Court heardCraig Topen smashed a man with a golf clubByGordon CurrieMilo BoydReporter:,  Oct | commentsA dad rounded up masked vigilantes to attack a man he believed had sold drugs to his son. Craig Topen sped his Land Rover Freelander through a fence into one of the men he suspected before steering it into another.The -year-old then got out of his car to punch and kick a third man, before whacking him with a golf club, the Daily Record reports. Topen, who runs a joinery firm, admitted carrying out the attack which left Ilian Iliev scarred for le. Dundee Sherf Court heard Topen led a masked gang to the home of Iliev’s friend as he had been told he had been the cause of his son’s drug-related debts.  The court was told Topen drove at Iliev and his friends Kenneth McCluskey and Liam Cuthbert after being confronted by them outside the property. The accused then “repeatedly struck” Iliev’s head and body with a golf club, leaving him with three wounds to his scalp needing  stitches. Topen, from Dundee, admitted acting with others and, with their faces masked, attacking McCluskey, Cuthbert and Iliev in the city’s Craigmount Road on November , . He admitted mounting the pavement and driving at them before striking them with the vehicle, then getting out and attacking Iliev with a golf club. He also admitted having an offensive weapon, namely the golf club. Sherf Alistair Carmichael deferred sentence on Topen for reports and he was granted bail. title: dad covid dreamt tesco driver
story: :root Dad with Covid ‘dreamt he was a Tesco driver with rubbish van’ during -day comaPaul Luttrell revealed he suffered one long dream during his -day coma while he had Covid - where he was kidnapped by a gang and worked as a driver with a really crap vanPaul in hospital recovering from being in a coma Image: Paul Luttrell   SWNSByRosaleen FentonAudience Writer:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA man has told of the terrying dream he experienced while in an -day induced coma - where he was aposkidnapped and forced to be a delivery driver with a really crap vanapos. Paul Luttrell, , was placed on a ventilator after contracting Covid and it was feared he wouldnapost survive. Three years ago, he was diagnosed with myeloma, a cancer of the blood and bone marrow, that destroyed his kidneys. He was taken ill from Covid during a regular dialysis session and placed in an induced coma. But after defying the odds to recover, he has now given an incredible insight into the continuous delirium that came with being comatose.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here The former builder said he is still struggling to process what he experienced during the -day stretch. In his dream, he was aposkidnappedapos by a gang and fearing for his le at every moment while working as a driver. And as part of his apostortureapos he revealed he was made to work as a aposslaveapos delivering food for Tesco to earn his captors money - and was only given a clapped-out old banger of a van to work in. He said he doesnapost remember anything  until coming around three weeks later. He spent a total of  days in the coma and described the whole experience as apossurreal.apos He said: It was pretty hellish. I did not get to see my family or say goodbye and was put in an induced coma for  days. I remember the dreams so clearly - like crystal. I had been kidnapped by a gang in London who put a hood over my head, chucked me in a car and then took me to a garage. It was a really wet floor but they ripped my shirt and used a defibrillator to try and torture me. They then made me get a job as a Tesco delivery driver but I had to give all my money and wages to them. I only had this crappy van doors hanging off the back but I had to get on with it and earn more money to give straight to them. The leader of the gang was a dwarf who kept demanding aposI want more money.apos I then also started selling acid tabs. It was all so bizarre I donapost know where it all came from. But I was hallucinating and could not escape. They wanted me to look after a prostitute. I remember what she looks like and everything. My job was to protect her from guys getting too frisky with her. The dream went on continuously. The girl was a computer hacker and she worked with other hackers to find out who Banksy was as he was trying to kill the queen. There was a big event in London next to the Thames that had two giant pyramids. There was a film showing that night next to the pyramids that had three words displayed you are dead. I stopped to watch the movie and everything collapsed around me. It was scary stuff. The dreams were so bizarre but so real. I jumped from one place to another. I would hide under my friendaposs house and they would put out smoke signals when it was safe to come out. Paul, of Frome, Somerset, who has five children and two grandchildren, said his family thought they would aposbury himapos after he was put straight into isolation during the dialysis session on July . His oxygen levels had dropped to just  and the last thing he remembers was paramedics arriving dressed in hazmat suits. He added: What I was later told was that I was taken to hospital in Bath but they didnapost have facilities for a dialysis patient so I was moved to Southmead in Bristol. I went to ICU and was given dialysis continuously while I was asleep. I was so ill with Covid, the x-rays showed it was all over my chest and I was struggling to breathe so they put me on a ventilator and induced me. I donapost remember anything from the start until waking up. Paul said he also apossubconsciouslyapos heard his favourite music which his brother had asked medical staff to play for him. He also recalls the moment he finally came around. He added: My mum died a year ago and she used to train horses along the seafront in Weymouth when she was younger. She was riding bareback and just looked at me and smiled. That is when I woke up. It was like she wouldnapost let me die. I have had to come to terms with what is in my own head. Delirium is a recognised result of being in an induced coma. When you talk to people who have been in that position they say it can make you go mad - as it seems so real.  Paul has needed help with a physio and phycologist since he came out. He has also had to teach himself to eat and walk again. And when he came round he said the delirium continued. He added: The first thing I said to my we was have Tesla phoned  A week later I was still having nightmares. It appeared to me the nurses were operating on a double-decker bus by remote control. In their office was a desk with a steering wheel. Paul, who had to give up work after being diagnosed with cancer, is now recovering at home after being discharged on August  and is looking positively to the future. He added: From a physical side I was diagnosed with cancer three years ago that killed my kidneys. The cancer is still there and I still have dialysis but I am feeling stronger from being in a coma. It was almost like I was rebooted and needed the rest. I am just trying to live a normal le. I have dialysis three times a week into the arm but I am a positive person and try to see the best of my situation.But the doubters need to know that catching Covid is a serious thing. There are so many people without masks now there is no wonder we are in the trouble we are in. My sons really supported my we Dalma as it was a tough time for all of them. They all thought they were going to bury me and it was time for me to go. It shows what Covid can do to a family. It can destroy it. Dalma added: I have been ready to say goodbye to my husband for about three years now.When he caught coronavirus this summer, I thought he wasn’t coming home because they sayyou have underlying conditions it hits you harder.The doctors said he was a miracle. story: :root Castaways adrt in the Pacic survive  days by eating coconuts floating pastTwo castaways survived  days adrt in the Pacic Ocean by feasting on supplies of oranges and catching coconuts that floated past their boatThe men turned off the engine in the hopes of saving fuel but ended up floating over  miles off course Image: Getty ImagesByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsTwo men cast adrt in the Pacic Ocean incredibly survived for  days by eating coconuts which bobbed up to their boat and by catching rainwater. Solomon Islanders Licvae Nanjikana and Junior Qoloni set out from Mono Island on September  on what should have been a -mile voyage to new South Georgia. The experienced seamen had taken the trip before and planned to use visual markers to help guide their route. But the pair ran into disaster when torrential rain and heavy winds battered their small motorboat. During the storms, their GPS packed in and the men found themselves cast adrt in a notoriously rough and unpredictable stretch of water. “We have done the trip before and it should have been OK,” Nanjikana told the . Without global positioning, they had no way of telling which direction to turn. They decided to stop the engine in the hopes of saving fuel, Nanjikana said. The men had taken a store of oranges with them, which helped to keep them alive. Another source of food came in the form of coconuts bobbing along the waves. The men fought off dehydration by using a piece of canvas to catch falling rain. The duo floated  miles before being spotted by a fisherman off the coast of New Britain, Papua New Guinea. “We didn’t know where we were but did not expect to be in another country,” Nanjikana said.  The men were so weak when they were rescued on October  that locals had to carry them off the boat. They are currently living with a local resident in Pomio on the south of New Britain island. Nanjikana said the ordeal was a nice break from Covid, thereports. “I had no idea what was going on while I was out there. I didn’t hear about Covid or anything ,” he said. “I look forward to going back home but I guess it was a nice break from everything.” Earlier this year, a trio shipwrecked on a deserted island in the Bahamas were rescued after somehow surviving for  days.  The two men and a woman told their stunned rescuers they had managed to survive the epic ordeal by eating coconuts. The castaways claimed they swam to the uninhabited island after their boat capsized in rough waters. Dramatic footage captured the moment a chopper crew who spotted the marooned trio on a rocky outcrop dropped them le-saving supplies. The crew said the three people had desperately waved flags as the craft flew over Anguilla Cay, an uninhabited Bahama Banks island, during a routine air patrol on Monday. A US Coastguard helicopter crew filmed themselves parachuting the supplies from the aircraft. It captures the moment the three castaways stranded below realised salvation had finally arrived. The chopper crewaposs footage also captured a makesht encampment the group had built on the island. The man and two women, who were said to all be Cuban nationals, reportedly told their rescuers they had been stranded for about five weeks on the archipelago, which is located between Cuba and the Florida Keys. None of the castaways appeared seriously hurt, the United States Coast Guardtold reporters. The Rubber Shop was an Aladdin#s cave of gts and homeware # and an Aberdeen institution for nearly a century.With a reputation for quality items at low prices, it was a popular emporium for bargain-hunters, especially at Christmas time when its shelves overflowed with the latest toys.Most Aberdonians will best remember The Rubber Shop on George Street, but the one-stop-shop first opened at  St Nicholas Street as Gauld and Company.The firm was an Indian rubber and waterproof dealer selling soft goods and hosepipes.Join us on a step back in time reminiscing over a much-loved but long-gone city centre business.The St Nicholas Street shop acquired the London Rubber Company, which had its headquarters at Drummond Street in Inverness, and began trading under that name in Aberdeen.It was known colloquially as The Rubber Shop and took on this name officially in October , as well as expanding its range of wares to include toys and sports equipment.Celebrating its th anniversary in , the proprietors put its success down to #an iniduality peculiar to itself#.The firm, which remained in the Fowler family for its -year existence, went from strength to strength and outgrew its extended premises on St Nicholas Street.And in the s, the decision was made to move the shop to a larger building nearby at  George Street, pictured above, big enough to accommodate #a stock of more than , golf clubs#.In , Doris Fowler, managing director and widow of the founder#s grandson said: #The Rubber Shop is really three shops in one. There is the sports department, which is  a joy to those in tennis, swimming or allied pursuits.#And there are the toys which intrigue adults as much as children.#Traditional favourites find ready buyers, but at the same time the best ideas in new games and toys are to be found in The Rubber Shop, which keeps very much in tune with the times.#The shop promised to cater for all budgets and occasions stocking everything from exquisite crystal souvenirs and child-sized teddy bears, to ministers# dog collars and deckchairs.At Christmas , the must-have gt from The Rubber Shop was a leather-covered wine decanter #at a modest price#.And #for the man keen on gadgets, a battery-powered pencil sharpener and matching aluminium paperclip holder#.But those preferring a cosy Christmas gt could also pick up cable-knit sweaters and moccasin slippers.Meanwhile, it was said the sports enthusiast #really came into his own# in the sports department, pictured above in .Here Aberdonians could purchase jodhpurs, rubber riding boots, sports kits and tennis racquets.The shop enjoyed a close relationship with sporting groups in Aberdeen the founder#s son Ian Fowler had been honorary president of the Aberdeen Lawn Tennis Association and honorary vice-president of the city#s table tennis league.But despite its success and place in the hearts of Aberdonians, The Rubber Shop closed in  # just four years short of its centenary.Uncertainty over the redevelopment of George Street forced the Fowler family to make the dficult decision to shut up the shop for the final time on May  .Mrs Fowler said the trading conditions have become #impossible# due to the opening of the St Nicholas Centre nearby and the proposed Bon Accord Centre development.It was unknown what would happen to the buildings on George Street and Mrs Fowler added: #There was no way we could take on other premises without knowing the outcome of negotiations for the sale of our George Street shop.#It was an emotional day as Mrs Fowler bid goodbye to her  full-time and nine part-time staff, many of whom had served the family business for decades.She said: #They are all so sad. The girls have been crying, every now and then.#And the closure of The Rubber Shop was a regretful day too for long-standing customers who had come to know and trust a business built on family tradition.See more like this:For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

challenged Scotland to take complete control of their World Cup qualying destiny by defeating Israel.Clarke insists the fact Scotland are bidding to end a  year wait to compete in a World Cup finals underlines how dficult qualying is.He claims statisticians only gave the Scots an outside % chance of reaching Qatar  when the qualication campaign began.The Scots boss insists chances of qualication rocketed up to % following a - defeat of rivals Austria in Vienna last month.Now as Scotland host Israel at a sold out Hampden, Clarke has called for a victory that will make the his side odds on favourites to finish second and secure a play-off berth.Scotland currently occupy second spot in Group F and hold a one point advantage over third placed Israel.Clarke said:  #Somebody said we still only have a % chance of qualying for the World Cup.#That shows you how dficult it is for a country like ourselves to come out of this section.#But we were looking at a % chance before the Austria game of claiming second position and now we are up to %.#We need to make sure now that we build on the two results we got last month, put us into a position to control second place.#We need to cement that against Israel.#Scotland#s victory over second seeded Austria in Vienna ensured Clarke#s side now control their own destiny.Should they defeat Israel the Scots will face group minnows Faroe Islands away on Tuesday and  Moldova away next month.Maximum points from the Israel, Faroe Islands and Moldova triple header would effectively secure second spot before the Scots close the campaign with a final Group F game against leaders Denmark at Hampden on November .Clarke said: #You always want to control your own destiny.#It’s up to us to continue that as we have put ourselves in a really good position.#I used to say it with my club sides,you went to a place where you weren’t expected to get a big result, get it and then don’t follow it up with the next game then it’s a result that goes to waste.#We don’t want to waste the energy and the quality from the - victory in the last game. We have to make sure we get another positive result this time.#Clarke is quick to dismiss any notion that Scotland#s win in Vienna has reduced the battle for runners-up spot into a two horse race between Scotland and Israel.Austria, he insists, cannot be discounted even though they are four points behind the Scots and lost - to Israel in Haa last month.He said: #I think it would be foolish to rule Austria out.#They showed in the summer they are a good team.#Austria  had a little dip, the last window wasn’t great for them but they are a proud nation and they’ll want to be better this time and next month.#They’ll be looking at the last four games and thinking about picking  points.#That’s how I imagine it. Obviously ourselves and Israel with the results against Austria have put us in a better position but the Austrians won’t give up just yet.’A packed Hampden will cheer on the Scots for the first time since the coronavirus pandemic struck in March last year.Clarke insists the capacity crowd is not only down to the easing of lockdown restrictions at games but also the willingness of the supporters to come to the qualier.He reckons the Tartan Army can deliver an edge against a side the Scots will be playing competitively for the seventh time in three years.Clarke said: #It’s strange to have to wait so long but obviously it has been strange times over the last two years for everybody.#It’s nice that we are finally in a position where we can sell out Hampden and also that we have managed to put ourselves in a position where the supporters are buying into it.#The supporters enjoyed being part of the European Championships in the summer and, okay, it didn’t quite go the way we wanted it to.#But I think the supporters enjoyed the fact they were involved in the tournament.#It was their tournament, they were there, they were in it.#Selling out this game tells you that the supporters want to get behind this group of players, which is fantastic for them.#And also a credit to them as well.’Clarke has no doubt a pm kick-off on a Saturday will lead to a Hampden Roar from the Tartan Army.He insists it is the job of himself and his players to ensure the home support have something to cheer for the entire ninety minutes.The national boss said: #The supporters before the game are going to be fantastic, we know that.#We know they will be fantastic at the start of the game.#If we can start the game well and get on top, then they can carry us a long way.#There will also be times in the game when we will be under pressure and have to control the game without the ball.#The supporters need to show they can be patient and get behind us when we need that bit of support. I’m sure they’ll do that.#For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: thought for the week september 24 2021
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowI had the wonderful privilege the other week of holding a new grandson for the first time.Isn#t it amazing how a new-born infant can grab hold of your heart  I was filled with so much love and pride and I prayed that his le would be blessed.It so happened that the Gospel reading set for the Sunday after I met my grandson was, in part at least, about a little child.​Mark tells us Jesus was walking ahead of his disciples on the way to Capernaum. When they got there Jesus asked them: #What were you arguing about along the way #They couldn#t answer, for they had been arguing about which of them was the greatest. They were silent, because they#d been caught out.Then Jesus took a little child in his arms and said to them: #Whoever welcomes one such child in my name welcomes me, and whoever welcomes me, welcomes not me but the one who sent me.#Greatness, Jesus was saying to them, is found in welcoming and receiving into our arms someone vulnerable, powerless and dependent, regardless of age.Greatness is found not in what we have accomplished but in what we have done and given to #the least of these#, the hungry, thirsty, naked, sick, and imprisoned: the symbolic children in each of our lives.Greatness never makes itself superior over another. It is not about me, my job, my reputation, my status. Our greatness is revealed in our service and care of others.Max is doing well, by the way, and I can hardly wait to see him again.God bless you and yours, from biggest to littlest, today and always.

title: letters to the editor september 24 2021
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Sir,Dr Jeremy Phillips and Dr Rebecca Helliwell wish to thank the community and patients of Mid Argyll Medical Practice for their kindness and good wishes marking their leaving the practice earlier this month.It has been a real privilege and honour to have been so closely and intimately involved with the lives of so many people and families over the last  and  years respectively.We will always be grateful for this and the opportunity to work with a excellent loyal and dedicated group of staff in the practice, hospital and in the wider NHS team.We will both continue to live locally and continue to work in the NHS in Argyll.Dr Jeremy Phillips and Dr Rebecca HelliwellSir,Looking into the future of marine planning, West Coast Regional Inshore Fisheries Grouphas formed an aquaculture sub-group to foster better communications and understanding between commercial fishing and aquaculture.Both are integral to coastal communities which are economically dependent on them.After the initial meeting it was agreed that there were synergies to be had working with other areas around Scotland, and the group was expanded to become simply the RIFG Aquaculture Working Group.The driving force comes from the proposed huge future expansion of aquaculture, the fact that fishers were not considered, historically, as mandatory consultees and also the promise of a review by Scottish Government of the aquaculture licencing process.It was felt that now was a good time for inshore fishers, through the RIFG, to consider, collate and communicate their views to any, and all, of the regulatory bodies involved in the said licencing process.The working group is particularly concerned with the aquaculture planning process # especially when it comes to the impact of proposed sites on traditional fishing grounds # poor site maintenance and monitoring which can lead to instances of vessel entanglement and also the environmental impact of the sites on both commercial and non-commercial species.The group believes that while the sector has made many advances over the past decade, increased transparency and oversight are needed to ensure the aquaculture sector can better co-exist with the fishing industry.The initial aim of the group would be to ensure that there is a proper analysis of localised fishing and follow up with clear and sensible communication between the two sectors to ensure that with expansion does not come conflict.It is a timeous idea, which will hopefully reassure fishermen that they will not simply be displaced by fish farming but will be respected for their own produce.The group will cement a policy to assist the fishing industry deal realistically with the fish farming industry and the Scottish Salmon Producers Organisation.Simon Macdonald, chair RIFG Aquaculture Work GroupSir,NFU Scotland is calling on the UK Government to address the nation’s growing labour crisis, which is undermining all parts of the food and drink supply chain, leading to signicant losses on some Scottish farms and resulting in a growing number of empty shop shelves.Last week#s #BackBritishFarmingDay on September  came as a UK Government announcement of a free trade #agreement in principle# between the UK and New Zealand is believed to be imminent.Having agreed in June to provide unfettered access in the future to Australia, the cumulative impact of another deal with a major exporting nation has huge signicance for Scottish farmers and crofters.With so much to celebrate about the quality and standards of our food and drink, #BackBritishFarmingDay was a fantastic opportunity to thank the nation for their incredible support throughout Brexit and Covid-.NFU Scotland, both independently and in conjunction with the Scottish food and drink industry, has written several times to UK Government calling for measures that address the shortfall in both seasonal and permanent staff.Should it fail to do so, I have absolutely no doubt that the situation will deteriorate further.It is galling to hear that the UK Government is on the verge of signing up to another free trade deal that will permit a growing level of imports while delivering very little to our food and drink sector in .The blunt fact is that neither deal has been afforded any kind of proper parliamentary scrutiny as the government’s promised Statutory Trade and Agriculture Commission has yet to be established.Safeguards against market disruption are also promised, but the cumulative impact of these deals will be profound for UK farming.If handled badly, these may make it impossible for some of our family farming businesses to continue to compete with high levels of low-cost imports produced to standards that would not be allowed here.Martin Kennedy, president, NFU ScotlandSir,National audits of diabetic services have shown that only around  per cent of people with type one or two diabetes have nine key annual checks to help prevent long-term diabetic complications.The pandemic has made this situation dficult because many routine checks and face-to-face appointments have not been available.The InDependent Diabetes Trusthas published a free new booklet which explains the nine key tests.It helps people look after their health by ensuring that they know what checks they need from health professionals.Get your copy of Diabetes care # your  key checks by contacting IDDT on  , emailing enquiries@iddtinternational.org or writing to IDDT, PO Box , Northampton NN XS.Jenny Hirst, InDependent Diabetes Trust
